results.title: The Developing image
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description: Explores the marvellous invention of the camera, using colour and music to evoke the period. This series takes viewers from the daguerreotype to wet plate to tintype and onwards examining hundreds of exemplary photographs. It dramatically depicts various themes in the history of photography.

results.title: The Developing child
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How much do we know when we come into the world? Rousseau believed we came into the world with all the skills needed for survival, and were then warped by our contact with society. John Locke, however, saw young babies as a blank screen to be developed by life’s experience. This began the “nature versus nurture” debate in human psychology. Philip Zimbardo, in this program, investigates current evidence to decide whether heredity or environment is the major factor in a child’s development.

results.title: The Detour
results.creator_credit: Shelby Leverington, Caroline Mouris and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: A film experienced entirely from the point of view of an elderly patient dying in a large hospital. As modern medicine struggles to keep eighty three year old Catherine Hamilton alive she struggles just as hard to die in peace. Each time she thinks she may be able to slip away, the doctors and nurses bring her back with a wonder drug, or a new machine. But Catherine continues to fight to control her own destiny with humour and dignity

results.title: The Desperate heart
results.brief_description: A modern dance solo based on a poem by John Malcolm Brinner describing the loneliness and agony resulting from the loss of a lover. A variety of camera effects and double exposures, combined with the dancing and reading by Valerie Bettis, produces an interesting experiment in modern dance film. Created, spoken and performed by Valerie Bettis; original music by Bernando Segall.

results.title: The Desert hopping mouse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Focuses on the spinifex hopping mouse of inland Australia to illustrate the many features it possesses which enable it to survive in what appears to be an extremely hostile environment. Also shows its daily activities, its methods of reproduction and the ways in which these may change with the seasons or from year to year. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Desert fox
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hills, Dennis Tupicoff and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: July, 1942, war veterans recall the best fighting animal of the era, and a great mate - the desert fox (who looks remarkably like Rommel), captured in a visual array of claymation, stop frame and animation in this war mockumentary.

results.title: The Desert dreamers (A)
results.creator_credit: Geoff Dunlop and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
A video about the paintings produced by the Papunya Aboriginal people, some 200 miles from Alice Springs. Looking like twentieth century abstracts, the paintings use an extremely complex symbolic language that relates to religious ceremonies. Some of them are outstandingly beautiful. All reveal the richness of desert Aboriginal life and culture. Shows the lives of the painters and their families, desert nomads who are being forced to come to terms with the realities of white technology, economics and values.
